Fields.DialogueText: It looks like your bad luck doesn't know when to quit. Morganas spotted in our vicinity!
Rest assured, Capitano. I'm not one to let a little misfortune stand in my way. Let's show these dragons what REAL bad luck looks like!
Buon giorno, Capitano. I've fixed you some breakfast.
Thanks a lot, Giorgio. I've been swamped recently.

Fields.MenuText: Have you always been this unlucky?
Do you think you could be cursed?
What's the unluckiest thing that's happened to you?

Fields.DialogueText: That depends on how you view our relationship, Capitano. If you believe my bad luck brought me to you, then that says more about how you view yourself.
I don't think so. Were I truly cursed, I would have sunk a long time ago!
Let's see... I ran aground in 1911 and spent a year being repaired, only to run aground AGAIN in 1913! No amount of spilled coffee could ever compare to the terror of being trapped like that.
*ALARM*
It's my specialty! Fette biscottate with a caffè latte! Careful, the coffee is piping-- HUAH!
*THUD*
I always thought my uniform could do with livening up. A dash of brown from the coffee and a sprinkle of white from the cream seems like just what was needed...
Apologies, Capitano! It looks like I just can't kick this bad luck!
@BATTLE
Now, I think it's best if I get a new set of clothes on quickly before these are permanently stained.
Of course, Capitano. I'll leave you to get changed. If you have any additional need for me, please don't hesitate to-- KYA!
*THUD*
Are you all right, Giorgio?!
It seems my earlier spill has made the floor a little slippery. Be careful how you maneuver about your quarters, Capitano. I'll be back shortly to help clean this-- IYA!
*THUD*
I'll go get a mop for you, Giorgio. You just focus on staying still. Perfectly, perfectly still.
Aye-aye, Capitano...
Giorgio, do you believe in destiny?
Destiny implies my choices don't matter. Such a thought makes me a little uncomfortable.
I was trying to justify why you suffer so many accidents. I thought you might be cursed!
*ALARM*
The only thing cursed here are these Morganas. Let's deal with them quickly, Capitano!
@BATTLE
I believe destiny, like curses, is all about outlook.
How do you figure?
For example, St. George bested the dragon in Libya—now in Italian possession. Should I fight to protect that land I hold so dear, I may very well be martyred there.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think of Morganas as the dragons of the sea?
How did George defeat such a monster?
Are you so fond of Libya?

Fields.DialogueText: I do, Capitano. Fear not—you aren't traveling with a Belle who is deranged. Viewing Morganas as evil beasts with no hope of redemption just makes them easier to fight.
Physically, it was nothing more than a simple beheading. Variations of the legend tell of a spear to the heart preceding the final blow, as well. However, I consider his perseverance to be the key.
I hold more of a sentimental attachment when compared to Genoa, for example. Despite Italy being my birthplace, every ounce of my body calls me to Libya.
Some people might see my destiny as cursed. However, I think that laying down my life to protect something important to me can only be considered a blessing. Wouldn't you agree?
I never thought about it like that. I guess you're right in some way.
Of course, I won't leave you behind, Capitano. You can't get rid of me that easily!
Va bene, Capitano... I'm used to this by now...
*BOMF*
Giorgio, watch out! The deck's just been swabbed!
Ah, Capitano, I've been looking for--
There you are, Giorgio. I've been looking for you.
Ah, Capitano! I'm surprised you found me down here.
Why would you want to spend your day in the engine room?
You know I'm not one to run from trouble, but... take a look at these.
What are these papers? "Mi belezza, your smile is royal and one of nobleza." Poems?
The crew were insistent that I hold on to them. I'm not one for socializing at the best of times, so you can imagine my distress.

Fields.MenuText: Are you fond of poetry?
At least they're flattering, if this is anything to go by.
Do you have a favorite poet?

Fields.DialogueText: Italy popularized so many forms of musical literature, but I've always struggled to understand the hidden meanings poets want to express.
"My beauty, your smile is royal and one of nobility." It's touching.
I'm not too knowledgeable of poetry. But after I learned that Angiolo Silvio Novaro passed away last year, I started to read his old works and enjoyed them thoroughly.
Oh, but what am I supposed to do? I can't stay down here all day, but the embarrassment is killing me!
That explains why everyone upstairs is scribbling away in their notebooks.
Right?! I've received all these poems but... there's just no room left in my binder to accommodate them all! The shame of having to reject a gift is just too much!
Wait, you're flustered by the physical papers and not by what they're writing about?
I'm not annoyed at the content at all, Capitano; these poems are beautiful! I truly hope that whoever they're written for will be able to read them someday.
Giorgio, I hate to be the one to tell you this, but these poems are all written about--
*ALARM*
You know what? Forget it. I've never been a fan of poetry anyway. How about we deliver a touching eulogy for these Morganas instead?
I'm right behind you, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Understanding them is different, of course... but I like where I've started.
You know, I don't think I've ever asked what it's like for you as a Belle in the Regia Marina. Have you had much chance to work with the other Italian Belles outside of our operations?
"Outside of our operations?" Hm. I used to sail with my sister on occasion, but the Belle I've worked with the most is probably Pola.

Fields.MenuText: And what do you make of her?
Ah. That must have been exciting.
Do you have any crazy Pola stories?

Fields.DialogueText: She's a handful, Capitano! Normally, I prefer to analyze a situation before rushing in guns blazing. But if Pola dives headfirst into a fray, it's my responsibility to chase after her.
Oh, si. She brings a great deal of enthusiasm to her work.
Well, I don't mean this in a bad way, but she has a way of forgetting her duties and picking fights with any Belle who looks at her funny. Not to the death, or anything!
Pola sounds like quite the character.
*ALARM*
Think you two could win this war on your own?
Nobody can, Capitano—but I'm more than sufficient in dealing with these brutes right here!
I don't doubt it!
Besides, I taught Pola everything she knows! Now, let's put that knowledge into practice!
@BATTLE
It's funny. I was based in Pola, the city, as a training ship.
I sometimes wonder if Pola the ship is going out of her way to do what Pola the city can't.
I didn't particularly enjoy sitting around all day being fired at - especially when the Morganas were doing the firing - so I decided to take to the seas again.
... Perhaps it's best if I don't share the crazy ones, Capitano.
That bad?
... That I know about.
It's nice to finally get onto land and stretch my legs!
Enjoy yourself while you can. We shouldn't be here for too long.
What a beautiful couple! You must have traveled for some time. A rose for the lady?
Don't feel the need to pamper me, Capitano. Although that bouquet does smell divine...
Can those roses cut through a Morgana's hull, by any chance?
Ah, you and La Bella Fantasma are warriors of the sea. In that case, perhaps you look into my other wares.
What exactly are these "other wares?"
They're similar to roses. Just a bit more... explodey. What say I give you a great price?
Some other time.
I'm all the firepower this ship needs!
I tell you what. You buy bouquet, I throw in autographed drawing by Walt Disney as well. No forgery; I know a guy.
Capitano! The poor man is just trying to make a living! We can't deprive him of giving us that auto-- I mean... earning an honest day's wages, right?
Fine, we'll take them both. Looks like we'll be able to test how deadly these roses are sooner than I thought.
Morganas attempting to dock! Better pop a rose in your mouth, Capitano. It's tango time!
@BATTLE
Thank you for buying me the flowers, Capitano, grazie. And I will cherish this autograph forever!

Fields.MenuText: Since when were you such a Disney fan?
What's your favorite Disney work?
Do you prefer Italian films or American films?

Fields.DialogueText: I haven't seen many, but I loved Snow White! And to hold in my hands something by the creator... oh, I could sing!
Over the years, my crew occasionally traded with American ships. I've managed to find a reel here and there!
The two are vastly different and hard to compare. However, gun to my head, Disney is too magical to forgo.
Let's get back onto the ship and frame this before it's damaged.
Grazie ancora!
Be careful not to let go of that autograph, Giorgio, or Neptune will have his turn to fawn over it.
Don't worry, Capitano. I don't think I could let go of it if I tried.
I'm wondering why a dragon slayer is so entranced by a princess surrounded by dwarfs.
Capitano, you shouldn't discredit it! At its core, Snow White is a story of rescue! The princess is rescued by the seven miners and is subsequently saved by her prince.
If you really want to get into American media - when it comes to rescue, I'm not sure if the likes of Sleepy and Sneezy could compete with Superman or Slam Bradley.
No, Capitano, you're missing the point! Rescue isn't about otherworldly physical strength. It's about doing something big even if you feel small.
Unlike Superman, I'm far too small to throw a car at someone. However, I'm GRUMPY at these Morganas and HAPPY to take them out!
That's the spirit, Capitano! I'm right behind you!
@BATTLE
For as long as this war rages, I will rescue Italy from all who strive to harm it.

Fields.MenuText: Hopefully you won't be in it alone. There's the League, obviously, and Italy's relationship with Germany in particular...
Strange question, but - do you know Italy well? Have any favorite places?
You saw some fighting in the last war, didn't you? This isn't all new to you.

Fields.DialogueText: It sounds cliché, but my birthplace of Castellammare di Stabia will always cradle my heart. Mount Vesuvius, the Roman city of Stabiae, the Bay of Naples—I'd love to take you there one day, Capitano!
Germany's obsessions don't extend to Italian well-being, Capitano. I desire nothing more than to extricate Italy from this war before any lasting damage is done.
Venice came under heavy fire against Austro-Hungarian forces in the Great War, and I saw occasional action at that time.
Hm. Understood.
When I first awoke, I struck out to defend the furthest of Italian colonies. By my side stood a crew of passionate compatriots who would die for their homeland.
I can't imagine too many Belles were interested in picking fights at that time.
You'd be surprised, Capitano! Amerigo Vespucci set off west at almost the same time I headed east! We were quite a lot for the Regia Marina to handle at first.
What was she doing?
Searching for a new world. We all serve our country in our own ways.
What is it you're holding this time, Giorgio? Your prized autograph or more poetry?
Actually, it's a letter from my sister, San Marco.

Fields.MenuText: When was the last time you spoke with her?
Are you two close?
How is she doing?

Fields.DialogueText: We worked together somewhat during the Great War, but she mainly focused on targeting submarines. Since then, we've barely stayed in contact.
That good-for-nothing younger sister of mine would rather waste her talents as a target ship than do anything of worth. We can never seem to see eye-to-eye on anything!
Open it up, then. Let's see what she wrote.
I still haven't opened it yet. I'm a little nervous to see how she's doing.
Before that, we should clear out those encroaching Morganas!
@BATTLE
OK then, let's see what exactly San Marco has to say for herself. I'm looking forward to reading all of her excuses as to why-- KYA!
I'm curious to see if San Marco is as much of a klutz as you are, Giorgio...
My letter! It's going to be ruined if we don't fish it out quickly, but all of our supplies are back on the ship!
Stand back, Giorgio!
*SPLASH*
Capitano!
There we go. Good as new!
Capitano! You didn't have to dive in to retrieve that for me! You must be positively freezing. Let's return quickly and get you a towel!
I didn't just dive into that body of water to not hear what San Marco has to say. Go ahead, read it aloud.
As long as you're sure... "Training going well. Be safe."
That's it?!
I tried to tell you, Capitano! We just aren't that close.
Well, isn't that just-- ACHOO!
Let's get you into something warm, Capitano. Come with me.
Ah, hell. I think I've come down with something after leaping into that water.
I take full responsibility, Capitano. As such, I will be sure to nurse you back to health personally.
What does that entail?
Were you unaware? Italy has a wealth of traditional home remedies known to cure almost any ailment.
For a light cold, we could try herbal tea made from thyme, sage, mint, and rosemary.
That sounds nice.
We could also try sipping mulled wine.
That sounds even nicer!
Or, I could fix you a dish known to cure any stomachache. A bowl of white rice topped with raw lemons!
After hearing that, I think I might need two cups of wine instead.
*ALARM*
Morganas! Are you okay to fight, Capitano?
I'm not one to let a simple bug keep me from my duties! Lead the way!
@BATTLE
We shouldn't have any more disturbances, so you lie down and let me take care of everything.

Fields.MenuText: How do you know so much about home remedies?

Fields.DialogueText: I spend so much time with people from all walks of life that I suppose I just picked them up without noticing!

Fields.MenuText: Have you tried any of these remedies yourself?

Fields.DialogueText: Most definitely! Except for the lemon one. However, the old woman who described the remedy swore by it!

Fields.MenuText: Do you know any other strange home remedies?

Fields.DialogueText: One that I can't seem to wrap my head around is using brandy to cure a toothache! I think it may just be an excuse to drink away the pain!
I'll fetch you some tea, Capitano! Don't move a muscle!
I'm back, Capitano!
*SNORE* *SNORE*
Oh! Are you sleeping, Capitano?
*SNORE* *SNORE*
Please enjoy some well-deserved rest, Capitano.
I will leave your tea by your bedside.
That way, when you wake up, you can refresh your senses with this scalding hot-- KYA!
*THUD*
HOOOOOOT!
Capitano, I'm sorry! I just wanted to bring you some tea to aid in your recovery.
I can feel my blood boiling inside of me!
*ALARM*
Perfect timing! I need to blow off some steam!
@BATTLE
How are you feeling, Capitano?
Honestly, a lot better! I think that spill shocked the cold out of my system!

Fields.MenuText: I think you'd make a great nurse, Giorgio.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? Perhaps I could do some good... for the patients I don't accidentally kill.

Fields.MenuText: Have you ever thought about a different career?

Fields.DialogueText: I'm a Belle first and foremost, but I'll always be drawn to teaching. I have so many experiences under my belt and would love to be able to share them.

Fields.MenuText: Could you stop making me hot drinks, Giorgio?

Fields.DialogueText: I suppose I might have to. Ooh! I know of another ice cold latte that is sure to put a spring in your step!
Now that I'm on the mend, let's get out of this room and see what the skies have on offer!
Molto bene, Capitano!
Capitano, can you see that flailing mass on the horizon?
I can't see... Wait, what IS that?!
I assumed it was some new breed of flying fish, but it seems to be more similar to a marlin in size.
I'll fetch my telescope.
*FOOTSTEPS*
What do we have here... Egad! That's no fish! It's a marooned sailor! He's floating atop what appears to be remnants of his ship!
What's your operative, Giorgio? Giorgio...? Where has she--
*ALARM*
Capitano! Please hold onto something to avoid being thrown overboard! I'm about to kick these engines into overdrive!
Giorgio, wait! It'll only take twenty minutes to reach him normally! We don't need to rush so-- MUUUUH!
Looks like my instincts were right, Capitano! He's fleeing from a group of Morganas. If we had waited any longer, they would have caught up to him!
In that case, let's dispatch them quickly and bring him on board!
@BATTLE
I appreciate your speed in dispatching those foul things. They tore through my ship and left me marooned atop that shrapnel-ridden slab.
As long as you're all right, that's all that matters!
Unfortunately, the same can't be said of my crew. Most are lost, and we still have a pilot without a place to land - that's my scout plane up above.
How did we not notice that?
It's so high up, I thought it was a bird. I didn't want to mention it lest my bad luck invoke a sudden seagull bowel movement over my nice clean hull!
Why don't you head downstairs and take a rest? We'll see to your pilot and drop you off at the next port.
Much obliged.

Fields.MenuText: You really kicked it into overdrive back there, didn't you?
Can I expect the same level of intensity from you if I'm ever lost at sea?

Fields.DialogueText: I cannot sit by and watch something so terrible come to pass. I would burn my engines down to their last flame if it meant I could save even just one person.
Not just you, Capitano. I would have done the same for any man, woman or child in such a situation! Although, perhaps I would have gone a little faster in your case...

Fields.MenuText: I thought I was going to be thrown overboard!

Fields.DialogueText: I warned you to hold onto something, Capitano! When it comes to rescues, I just can't control myself!
This rescue mission has got me fired up all over again! I think I know what I must do. Libya will not protect itself and so I must be there at my final hour. I will stay by your side until then.
And I'll support you in any way I can, Giorgio!
Giorgio, there you are! Mind if I join you? I was interested in hearing more of your exploits before the war.
You seem awfully interested in my history as of late, Capitano. Are you quite sure you enjoy listening to my life stories so much?
If I didn't want to hear it, I wouldn't have asked, would I?
I suppose you're right. Very well, then! What exactly would you like to know?

Fields.MenuText: Where's your favorite destination besides Libya and Italy?
Do you have any other connections in Italy?

Fields.DialogueText: As silly as it is to say amidst a bloody battle, I can't help but feel a modicum of sympathy for Britain. Their fondness for St. George quells any desire for war inside me.
I often correspond with Crown Prince Umberto. It was me who conducted his tour of South America, after all. I dare say, speaking so much with that man has affected my speech tremendously.

Fields.MenuText: Did you have any hobbies back in Italy?

Fields.DialogueText: With so many popular hobbies in Italy, surprisingly, no. Like a Brit who hates tea, I loathe all things football and have been scolded by my crew for throwing their jazz records overboard!
*ALARM*
Looks like we'll have to continue your biography after dealing with these Morganas.
Let's send them to sleep with a little bedtime story instead!
@BATTLE
It sounds like you've lived quite the life, Giorgio. I'm relieved to have someone so well-traveled under my command.
Many people often tell me they idolize the things I've done, but I'd much rather spend my days relaxing at a bathhouse.
Well, I'll be sure to have you invite me to one after we're relieved of our duties.
I'd like that a lot, Capitano.
*FOOTSTEPS*
Now, if you'll excuse me, Capitano, I have some things to attend--
Giorgio! Watch out for that banana peel!
Phew! Capitano, you saved me. You might just be my good luck charm.
Giorgio? Are you in here?
Why can't these @#$%&! marines just @#$%&! for once in their @#$%&!-forsaken lives!
Blimey! The last time I heard a sailor with that kind of mouth, we washed it out with soap!
Capitano! What are you doing here?! I thought I had the bridge to myself!
I heard we received a message, so I came to check on it. Little did I know that Rhett Butler from Gone With The Wind had become an honorary Belle!
My deepest apologies, Capitano. You were never meant to hear that! I just got off the radio with them now, but...
But...
Ugh! They're driving me crazy. You know me, Capitano. I'm not one to fly off the handle, but the incompetence of some of these sailors is deplorable!

Fields.MenuText: What's the problem?
You've never made a mistake before?
Where did you pick up such language?

Fields.DialogueText: Our supplies are being delayed by a week due to a crewman's error. In my humble opinion, lazy mistakes like this shouldn't happen!

Italian is a very expressive language, Capitano! We live to convey emotions with words and even gestures. Scratching the underside of your chin incorrectly in Italy could rub some people the wrong way.
I've made my fair share of errors, I can admit. However, my mistakes don't affect my work. When it comes to beating Morganas, I never fail.
Still, if people heard such profanity aboard this ship, they might think us to be pirates!
Understood, Capitano. I'll control myself going forward.
*ALARM*
... Capitano?
Fine. You can curse like a sailor ONLY when fighting Morganas!
Sì, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Say, Giorgio, you can speak Spanish, right?
Spanish, Italian, English, Arabic, and a little Chinese.

Fields.MenuText: What do you think of Spanish?
Arabic's useful around the Mediterranean.
Chinese can't have been easy.

Fields.DialogueText: Aside from Italian and English, Spanish is my third fluent language. I spent a long time in Spain during the Civil War and picked it up during my stay. The grammar is similar to Italian, which helped.
I can only speak Levantine Arabic, but it pales in comparison to my Spanish or Italian. When I was stationed in the eastern Mediterranean I learned a little to help communicate with the locals.
Chinese was probably the most difficult language I've ever had to learn, next to English. The pronunciation is so difficult!
Do you think you could teach me a little something, perhaps? If we're to part at Libya, I'd like something to remember you by even if it's only a few choice words.
I'd love to, Capitano! Languages open so many doors and allow those I rescue to feel comfortable hearing their mother tongue.
Great! Well, fire away! I'm all ears.
*SOME TIME LATER*
How can you not understand this?! It's so easy!
Shouting isn't going to make me understand it any better!
A child could remember this grammar without difficulty! I think you might be a lost cause, Capitano...
*ALARM*
Phew! Saved by the bell!
Where do you think you're going, Capitano? The Morgana alarm doesn't dismiss you—I do!
Let's return to our studies after a brief recess.
Well... it is my duty as a teacher to exact punishment on naughty students. All right, let's give these delinquents a lesson they won't soon forget!
@BATTLE
Capitano, would you like a fig? I thought you might be hungry.
I'd love some, Giorgio. Thanks a bunch.
*WIND*
Let me rephrase. "I'd love some, Giorgio, thanks a stem!"
I couldn't help myself, Capitano. Figs are my Achilles' heel! I saved at least one for you, so please enjoy it...
I appreciate you saving one for me, but that scowl you're wearing makes me think it was done out of necessity. Here, you have it.
Capitano, you're such a charmer. Thank you very much.
Where did you get these, anyway?
I traded an unused engine part with a member of the crew who in turn traded that with some foreigners for some figs to share!
Was it okay to lose a piece of yourself so easily?
It was barely functional and in need of an upgrade anyway. As long as we don't run aground before the next stop, it should be plain sail--
*SKRUUUUNK*
Famous last words, huh, Giorgio? I didn't want to say I told you so, but--
*CREEEEEAK*
Whoa, Giorgio where did this hug come from? Are you all right?
E-ever since I ran aground twice back in 1911 and 1913, I-I've n-never been good being c-confined to one spot.
Sorry for teasing you, Giorgio. I had no idea it was such a problem for you.
Me la caverò. Just let me stay by your side, Capitano, until the crew dislodge us.
*RUMBLE*
KYA!

Fields.MenuText: I've never seen you so timid, Giorgio.

Fields.DialogueText: It can't be helped... Belles are made up of many layers, just like humans. It's just unfortunate that my hidden trait is one of cowardice.

Fields.MenuText: It's nice to be able to protect YOU for once.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't get used to it, Capitano. It is my job to protect all who ride with me. Being seen like this is so shameful...

Fields.MenuText: I'm sure it will be over soon.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope so, Capitano. I don't know how much longer I can sustain this.
Being stuck here makes us sitting ducks for these Morganas. Think you can snap out of it long enough to deal with them?
Of course, Capitano. I am a professional and the distraction might do me some good!
@BATTLE
Thank you again for allowing me to wait out the grounding in your quarters.
It shouldn't be much longer now. How about you stop pacing so fervently and take a seat?
I don't understand how you can sit so placidly during such a crisis!
I was only trying to help.
Mi dispiace, Capitano. I just... I don't do well in situations like this. You're right. Let me have a seat.
Here, you can have my chair.
Capitano, I couldn't! It would be akin to sitting atop a king's throne!
I'm no king and right now my mission objective is to make you feel as comfortable as possible. So sit. That's an order!
... Grazie, Capitano.
Shall we practice your apology speech to the rest of the crew for when they dig us out?
S-s-s-speech?! Like... in front of people?!
You've got to be kidding me...
Don't look at me like that, Capitano! Morganas don't stare straight into my eyes when we fight, and that's just how I like it!
*ALARM*
Speak of the devil. Let's deal with these quickly and then reconvene.
@BATTLE
It's no use. I just can't perform knowing all eyes are on me.

Fields.MenuText: Have you tried picturing your audience naked?
What if you looked straight ahead instead of at your audience?
Could you close your eyes during the speech?

Fields.DialogueText: I think that would make me look deranged! Besides, it would all be for naught the moment I opened my eyes to read my cue cards.
Capitano! Who have you been conversing with that would give you such vulgar advice as that?!
It may work. Although, should I witness another drifter in need of rescue, I wouldn't be able to concentrate!
Wait! Capitano, I have an idea! Meet me in the bridge in thirty minutes! I need to search for something in my room!
Capitano? Are you still here? It's rude to keep a lady waiting, you know.
Sorry, Giorgio, I was just checking on the grounding. We should be free any moment now. What did you run off to find?
Ecco!
Let's have a closer look. What is this? A stuffed dragon toy?
One of my old sailors got it for me. At that time, I was even less confident in myself. You could say he encouraged me like an older brother.
So this is your secret weapon.
He said it would help me take myself less seriously. With my wonderful present in my hands, I feel like I could do anything!
*ALARM*
I hope that includes taking down some Morganas.
You bet it does!
@BATTLE
Do a test run first without the toy. Let's see what we're working with.
"I-I-I w-wanted to a-a-apo-apologize for... is that a stain on the door?! Someone should have alerted me! I would have cleaned it immediately!"

Fields.MenuText: Wow... that was... wow...
I'm not sure you could distract an entire crowd for the entire duration of your speech.

Fields.DialogueText: Was it that bad? I'm truly hopeless...
As long as it's long enough to escape from the spotlight, that works for me...

Fields.MenuText: Maybe we could pull off some sort of ventriloquist act instead. Would you be opposed to sitting on my knee?

Fields.DialogueText: Normally I'd scold you for suggesting such a thing... but truth be told, I'm actually considering it.
I may have ties with royalty, but at the end of the day, I'm nothing more than a glamoured-up beat-stick used to bust up Morganas...
That's not true, Giorgio! You've taught me so much about the world and I've loved being in your company so far.
Capitano?
You speak to me with such vigor and such passion on a daily basis. What if you just imagine you're having a conversation with me?
I'll give it a shot. "I-I-I... I wanted to apologize for endangering us so thoughtlessly. Rest assured it will never happen again."
Giorgio, you did it!
I did it! I knew that stuffed toy dragon wouldn't let me down!
Uh, Giorgio? I never gave the toy back. You did that all on your own.
No, Capitano. You and I both know that this was a team effort.
Attention, Captain. We have successfully dislodged and will be preparing to set sail shortly.
Oof! Wait, Giorgio, why are you hugging me? Didn't you hear the radio? We've been set free!
I heard. Only, for the first time... I'd hoped to be run aground that extra second longer.
No, I just... I'm impressed you actually wrote it out.
Well, after that debacle, we're back on track to return to Libya.
Albeit in fits and starts.
I'm surprised to see your Morgana killing technique has not wavered even slightly, even after suffering a minor setback.
Being as unlucky as I am, I learned to roll with the punches fairly early on in my career.
The princess of legend initially beckoned St. George to retreat, but he perservered and saved 15,000 men!
Bad luck, claustrophobia, public speaking—they're all nothing but a princess's words in my ear as I ride into battle to slay the wicked Morganas!

Fields.MenuText: Do you think a real dragon could beat a Morgana?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't be so childish, Capitano. The answer to such a question poses no value to us whatsoever. Although, if dragons DID exist, the Morganas wouldn't stand a chance!

Fields.MenuText: How do you stay motivated amidst such a storm of misfortune?

Fields.DialogueText: Were I to stay dormant during an attack, my crew would suffer. All that I do is done just for you, Capitano. And the several hundred sailors you keep on the payroll, but that sounds less eloquent.

Fields.MenuText: Have you ever used a sword before?

Fields.DialogueText: I've trained with a sword and a spear. I've even dabbled in the lance as well. Although I have to admit, it would be tricky for me to return to a melee weapon after wielding a mighty torpedo!
I won't tell you to hold back anything against these dragons, Giorgio! Morganas ahead!
I wouldn't have it any other way!
@BATTLE
Capitano, come quickly! We've spotted an island and it looks like there's a shipwrecked crew there!
What are we waiting for?! You're rubbing off on me, Giorgio—I can't move fast enough!
*WHISTLE*
Let's get this thing moving! Full speed ahead!
It looks like there are few Morganas obstructing our foward path. Let's be done with them and continue our rescue mission!
@BATTLE
It shouldn't take too much longer to reach that island.
I pray that any survivors have not given up hope of rescue.

Fields.MenuText: What inspires you to protect people so much?

Fields.DialogueText: My namesake fought bravely to protect a city of people. I will lay down whatever I can to honor the name I have been blessed with.

Fields.MenuText: Isn't it tiring, trying to rescue so many people?

Fields.DialogueText: I can work tirelessly in this life and rest in the next or rest for a short duration now and live an afterlife of regret. I know which one I'd rather choose.

Fields.MenuText: Would you rescue someone you knew was villainous?

Fields.DialogueText: I would, Capitano, and I would let him have his day in court. Such a way of thinking is what separates us from animals and the ghastly Morganas.
Anyone who sets out to sea is not one to give up after something as commonplace as a marooning. We'll get them on to the ship posthaste!
Sì, Capitano!
That island is much smaller than I thought it would be.
And a group of Morganas are circling it like hungry piranhas!
Let's clear them out quickly and send a team to retrieve any survivors!
Good thinking, Giorgio! You know what comes next!
Ready and waiting, Capitano!
@BATTLE
While we wait for the ground team to return, shall we discuss what may come to pass at Libya?
I personally have no qualms with the road I've decided to take, but I did not want to distress you in any way, Capitano. I know how much you value your crew.
You're more than just another crew member to me, Giorgio! You're asking me to deliver you unto the Grim Reaper's doorstep!
We seem to be going in circles, huh, Capitano? You see my inevitable sacrifice as disheartening, whereas I welcome the chance to martyr myself for my homeland with open arms.

Fields.MenuText: How can you value your life so little?

Fields.DialogueText: It's not that I place no value on my life. I just value that which is important to me more.

Fields.MenuText: What will I do after you're gone?

Fields.DialogueText: You'll sail the seas as you always have, with my memory by your side.

Fields.MenuText: Is there no other way?

Fields.DialogueText: In a perfect world, my firepower alone would be enough to keep Libya from harm. Sadly, that doesn't seem to be the case.
You might be one of the strongest people I've ever met, Giorgio.
True strength is the resolve to keep moving forward. Speaking of which, I think I can hear the expedition team returning. Let's go see if they found anyone.
Thank you so much for-- *COUGH COUGH*
It's okay. Catch your breath.
We're just happy to see that someone survived.
What happened?
We were transporting some goods when out of nowhere, a group of Murders attacked us and sunk our cargo.
That's terrible! Capitano, we have to send another expedition team pronto and find the rest of the crew!
Don't bother. I know for a fact I'm the only one who made it out of that chaos alive. Again, I can't thank you enough.
Don't be thanking me. It's this rescue-crazed Belle you should be thanking.
Right, right. I owe you my life, miss.
Live that life to the fullest and consider the debt repaid.
I don't suppose you're interested in adding to your crew. What I lack in physical strength, I make up for in resilience!
We could always use more lads to swab the decks. Consider yourself hired!
Be sure to make it spotless! I won't tolerate even a loose hair aboard my vessel!
Regardless, head down to the mess hall and get yourself a meal. You must be starving.
Right away!
That boy definitely said a GROUP of Murders, right? If so, where are they all?
Looks like you spoke too soon, Capitano! I see one now!
@BATTLE
I can see how that boy managed to survive for so long on this island. I can see five types of edible food from here!
And I spot a stream of what looks to be clear drinking water!

Fields.MenuText: What three things would you be marooned with on an island?
How long do you think you could survive on a deserted island?
Would you accept your fate having been marooned or try to escape?

Fields.DialogueText: If you rephrase that question to "would you mount a rescue mission for a sole survivor on an island?" I think you can guess my answer!
You know I don't do well in confined spaces, even something as large as an island! The moment I realize there's no way off, I'd start paddling!
Hmm, I'd need my dragon toy to deal with the claustrophobia. I'd need the bouquet of roses Capitano bought for me so I wouldn't lose hope. Oh, and I couldn't leave behind my autograph... only three?!
With the success of the rescue mission, let's head back out to open waters!
Aye-aye, Capitano!
Giorgio, thanks for coming to see me.
Is everything all right, Capitano? You seemed deathly serious earlier.
I think its time we discuss the true terror that threatens the lives of all who ride atop this ship on a daily basis.
Morganas!
Think again.
The impending war?
No, Giorgio. I'm talking, of course, about your terrible luck!
Capitano, you exaggerate! My luck isn't--
*RUMBLE*
I'm sure it's nothing...
I'm surprised we've managed to stay afloat this long. You can hardly walk a meter some days without tripping over something.
I don't disagree with you, Capitano. Yet, it's strange... recently I can't remember a time in which luck wasn't on my side.

Fields.MenuText: Do you think your curse has been lifted?

Fields.DialogueText: Superstitious as ever, aren't you, Capitano? You can't cure an illness that was never there in the first place!

Fields.MenuText: How long has it been since your last accident?

Fields.DialogueText: You know, I couldn't answer if I tried. Literally that long.

Fields.MenuText: Has this type of respite ever happened before?

Fields.DialogueText: Never! I could hardly go longer than a week without fumbling something.
Shall we test your good fortune on these Morganas?
Let's do it!
@BATTLE
Well, that went off without a hitch. It looks like you truly are cured!
Maybe we should run some tests. Then we can start to discern the reason as to why.
I have an idea. Meet me in the mess hall later.
OK, Giorgio. I've sent everyone to their quarters and laid out twenty-two banana peels between us. Your assignment: walk to me without falling over.
Couldn't we just flip a coin or something?
That wouldn't test for klutziness. Only luck.
OK, here goes nothing!
*ALARM*
Ah! What terrible luck!
I'm not so sure about that, Capitano. It seems like Fortune is trying to protect me more than anything. This trial is far more dangerous than any Morgana.
Let's get rid of them and return once they're dealt with.
@BATTLE
Come on, Giorgio! I believe in you!
This is going better than I expected.

Fields.MenuText: Are you feeling nervous?
What will you do first if your bad luck is gone?

Fields.DialogueText: I was at first, but I've settled into a rather fruity rhythm!
I'm going to get you that caffé latte like I tried to do all those days ago!

Fields.MenuText: Are the peels not slippery enough?

Fields.DialogueText: They're plenty slippery, Capitano, don't worry. It looks like I'm just able to step on them without worry!
One more, Giorgio! You can do it!
I think I'm going to make it! I think my bad luck has finally-- KYA!
Giorgio! Don't worry, I've got you. Rats, tripping on the last one. I guess your bad luck isn't gone after all.
I don't know about that, Capitano. You caught me, after all. Luck works in mysterious ways.
Capitano, have you seen my Disney autograph? I seem to have misplaced it.
I think you may have left it in my quarters during our last briefing. I've kept it safe in my top drawer.
Grazie. I would hate to lose something so valuable.
You seem to enjoy tall tales a lot, Giorgio. The legend of St. George, various forms of poetry, the works of Walt Disney... Have you ever thought about writing some fiction yourself?
I don't know what I would write about, Capitano. Or even if I would know how.

Fields.MenuText: Couldn't you write about one of your many experiences?

Fields.DialogueText: You mean like an autobiography? That would do away with the need for complex literary techniques, I suppose.

Fields.MenuText: You could write about me.

Fields.DialogueText: We have so many stories to tell that I fear that a single book could not contain them all!

Fields.MenuText: How about something short, like a poem?

Fields.DialogueText: Poetry does seem like the most accessible genre.
Poetry with its short structure but complex undertones should be good for a start. If all goes well, perhaps I could advance to novel writing.
*ALARM*
These Morganas should serve as good inspiration for a cruel and lamenting ballad!
I hold no such regret in administering these ships a well-deserved kick. I would liken their destruction more so to a limerick!
Nice rhyme, Giorgio! You're a deeply violent and aggressive poet and you kind of sort of already know it!
@BATTLE
Capitano? I was wondering you could critique this short poem I wrote.
I'd be happy to! What did you end up writing about?
I took your advice to heart and decided to write about my life and our time together.
I can't wait!
"As waves do crash upon the shore, we hold the line forevermore. Despite the lands I've come to know, they all do pale to Capitano."
That was...
Capitano, are you tearing up?
Of course not! It's just the glare from those Morganas that's irritating my eyes. We should deal with them quickly before I start to cry.
@BATTLE
It's still a work in progress, but I'd love to hear your opinion, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: It was amazing!
It's a little embarrassing.

Fields.DialogueText: I know I still have a long way to go, but your kind words of encouragement speak volumes!
I hold no shame in expressing how much I value my capitano!
So, what's next on the agenda? A novel? A series of novels? Am I looking at the next Charles Dickens?
Maybe I'll work on these poems a little longer. I should learn to walk before I learn to run, right?
Well, just remember I'm always here to lend an ear.
Will do, Capitano!
Now that we've confirmed your bad luck is all but gone, do you see your ideas changing at all with regard to the future?
My plans have not diverted, Capitano. I will go to Libya as planned and protect it until my dying breath.
I thought as much. There's just no stopping you, is there?
I'm afraid not. Still, if I am to embark on a quest of martydom, littered with evil hellships that want nothing more than to send me to a watery grave before my time...
It's at least nice to be in pleasant company along the way.

Fields.MenuText: I think your biggest rescue is yet to come.
I wouldn't mind being rescued by you now and again.

Fields.DialogueText: Giorgio... I've been meaning to tell you something for a while now.
*ALARM*
Let's deal with these Morganas first so we can talk without distractions.
@BATTLE
What did you want to tell me, Capitano? We've been through so much I feel as though you can tell me anything.
I've thoroughly enjoyed learning about not only your history, but your wants, fears, and annoyances as well.
I feel the same way about you, Capitano. It takes a special kind of human to catch a Belle whenever she stumbles.
Just don't get discouraged whenever you slip, all right? What was it you said about rescue? Doing something big even if you feel small?
What are you trying to say, Capitano?
The war has barely started, hasn't it? We'll have plenty of time to show the Morganas who this world belongs to!
I'd like nothing more, Capitano.
Even slaying Morganas?
Heh. That question's... easier to answer than I thought it would be.
Even if we stumble?
Especially if we stumble. With you by my side, I'll never stop moving!
